data.title: fix for interactive loader cache
data.body: As title suggests, interactive_loader() did not return cached resource and returned null object in gdscript. Can be reproduced by loading same scene twice, and this patch seems to work just fine.

data.title: Changing Window Size In Project Settings Changes Project Manager Size On Ctrl + Shift + Q
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux, Godot 2.0.3

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
On changing the window size via the Project Settings, on a quit to Project Manager (Ctrl + Shift + Q) changes the Project Manager window size. Doing fullscreen in Project Settings also makes the Project Manager fullscreen on quit to Project Manger as well.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Change the window size in Project Manager, or fullscreen it, then quit to the Project Manager via Ctrl + Shift + Q.

data.title: Documentation : BackBufferCopy, Light2D, LightOccluder2D
[Feature] GDscript comma chaining variable declaration
Nested whiles doesn't work as expected
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 Pro 64 bit - Godot 2.0.3.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Nested whiles seems to be running only the deepest loop.

This code:

```
    var i = 0
    var j = 0

    while i < 5:
        while j < 5:
            print (str(i) + " " + str(j))
            j += 1
        i += 1
```

is printing:

```
0 0
0 1
0 2
0 3
0 4
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
Use the code above.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Add support for Python-like negative indexing
data.body:
As a first step of implementing #4715 I started with negative indexing, since this is
useful in it's own right and a small change so I can get feedback on my coding style before wasting time in implementing something that will never be merged ;)

Negative indexing is a useful feature in Python, especially when combined
with array slicing. Array slicing will hopefully be implemented later, but
negative indexing is useful in it's own right.

A negative index is indexing from the end of an array,
"array[-1] == array[array.size()-1]", using a negative index
larger/smaller than the length of the array is still an error.

While primarily useful for arrays and strings, support is also added to
"array like" structures like Vector3 and Color. This is done just
to be consistent; vector3[2] is much clearer than vector3[-1], but disallowing
it while allowing it for an array with 3 elements seems confusing.

I'm on the fence on that last paragraph, I see no useful use case for it, but think it's better to be consistent and allow negative indexing everywhere. If there is a consensus to only support negative indexing for strings and arrays, I'm fine with changing the PR.

data.title: Fix MS Visual Studio build settings
data.body:
NMake was not setup by the vsproj=yes compilation
parameter. After attempting other possible options,
this is the best fix for our current requirements.
Compiling via NMake is implementing an alternative
to SCons, so this fix escapes out of NMake
environment while also supporting different target
builds and IDE error list integration.

Also sets -j setting to 2 so that it's easy for
people to change it to a propper value and speed it
up a bit for those that do not.

Adds two missing .gitignore Visual Studio temp files
present in Visual Studio's .gitignore.

@vnen care to test please? Win, correct?

data.title: MenuButton receives hotkeys expected by other MenuButtons
data.body:
**Godot version:**
2.0.3

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
`MenuButton` is receiving hotkeys (via `_unhandled_input`) that should be received by other `MenuButton`s.

**Steps to reproduce:**
The best way to reproduce the problem is by testing #4848. This PR makes `MenuButton` accept the events when used. This way a event won't be used more than once by `MenuButton`.
Open the shader editor and focus the 2D editor (with the shader editor still visible). Pressing <kbd>CTRL+F</kbd> will result in a search dialog for the shader editor instead of the expected _Frame Selection_ in the 2D editor (since the later is focused).
Without #4848, that hotkey would result in both _Frame Selection_ in the 2D editor and a search dialog in the shader editor.

data.title: Editor crashes with imported fonts in certain circumstances
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Arch Linux, Godot 2.1 Git (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/b6fdac80cb0716f4c64aed9d0920159b50e2ed15)

This issue seems to happen only with the Clang compiler. Version used here is `clang version 3.8.0 (tags/RELEASE_380/final)`. With GCC `gcc (GCC) 6.1.1 20160501`, this bug does not seem to occur.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

The editor will crash in at least two circumstances when using imported bitmap fonts:
- Double-clicking **res://** in the FileSystem tab with a font imported at the project root.
- Setting the editor font to an imported font.

After such a crash, if you re-open the project, it will crash again as soon as you open any scene, a few seconds after the opening, without leaving any error message.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome): [test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/287684/test.zip)

data.title: Conversion function for screen coords to local Canvas coords
data.body:
- Useful if you need to Convert screen coords to the coordinate space of a CanvasItem, but don't have an
  associated InputEvent to use in #make_event_local.

For example, if you have a particular point on the screen you'd like to project into World Space, for various reasons, you would use this function on the root of the scene.  This is analogous to ray casting from screen space in 3D.

data.title: Remove focus from Sprite Region Editor dialog. Fixes #4751
OS.get_window_size().height appears to be longer than actual window height
data.body:
For a window height of 600 OS.get_window_size().height returns 622

To me it seems like the height component of the Vector2 window  size adds the border height again. Because on OSX the window height includes the 22 pixels for the border.

Maybe I'm thinking could be that Godot wanted to allocate 622 pixels for the window to be 1024 x 600 as defined in the settings ? Because right now on OSX a window height of 600 has only 578 height since border occupies the other 22 pixels. But then again the window 0,0 begins just above the border so my guess is the height is calculated wrongly. 

Might be an OSX specific issue.

![screen shot 2016-05-27 at 8 08 41 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6987027/15623802/3a47c3e4-2447-11e6-8ded-355126d58c04.png)

I would like to propose to make the viewport tools more accessible, similar to UE4.
![deepinscreenshot20160528010806](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9007314/15623163/3e7fc2e8-2471-11e6-8616-67d8298c619e.png)

My first thought was to create a EditorPlugin script, but I was not able to find any way of modifying the snap settings in the editor that way. Is it possible to access somehow from script, or is c++ the only way?

data.title: MenuButton: Avoid key event propagation if handled as hotkey
data.body:
Just avoid propagating it when already handled.

~~e.g: When the 2D editor and the shader editor are both visible, pressing <kbd>CTRL+F</kbd> with a node selected, both editors will handle the event, no matter which one is focused. The 2D editor will do _"Frame Selection"_ and the shader editor will popup the search dialog.~~

~~#### Do Not Merge!:
This PR is incomplete. It just avoids propagating the event if it was used. However, there is still other bug with `MenuButton` that need to be fixed. Until it's fixed, this PR may result in an even worse usability problem.
That bug is that there is no priority when propagating  unhandled key events to `MenuButton`s. Therefore, considering the previous example, if this PR is merged, the events will always be used by the shader editor's menu instead of the menu whose editor is focused, which is the expected behaviour.
A possible fix could be to create a relation between the `MenuButton` and that editor/Container, and handle the hotkey event only if that editor is a parent of the focused Control (`is_a_parent_of()`). I don't know what would be the performance penalty though.
Here is an issue about this last bug: #4856~~

data.title: Proper one way collision for slopes
data.body:
This is a small reminder:
One way collisions work fine as long as the platform has no slope. As soon as the platform has a slope and you want to run up, you fall through. Here is a small video demonstrating the problem.

@reduz we discussed about making the one way vector relative to surface normal I think.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/m8qwwc5jhhcepx5/one_way_collision_bug.avi?dl=0

data.title: SamplePlayer cuts off the first sound if played twice or consecutively
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot_v2.0.3_stable_win64.exe

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create SamplePlayer Node (not 2d)
- Add a sample library
- Import sound effect

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

When you use `play()` twice in a row (or before the first sound is finished) -- it cuts off that sound file that was **played first**, and **starts the latest one again**.  Thus, you don't hear the entire sound of the first sound file being played... This shouldn't happen for sound effects. Each time `play` is called, the entire audio file should be played in its entirely, and consecutively (if it gets re-played again).

I submitted an issue (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/4764), but it's not really similar because that was for the `StreamPlayer` class, and is doing something different then what I'm describing here. (Delay in playing, as compared to blatantly cutting off the sound file in this issue) (Although, they could be correlated)

data.title: Lineedit control not reporting get_combined_minimum_size() correctly
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Using : Godot_v2.0.3_stable_x11.64 on linuxmint 17.3

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When building **Lineedit** control nodes from script, **get_combined_minimum_size()** mothod is not reporting correct size. For comparison **Label** control nodes are reporting meaningfull **combined_minimum_size** value. This makes resizing **Lineedit** to encapsulate its own content as same as **Label** impossible. 

This causes problem when these items are used inside GridContainer to form columns with different widths.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a scene. Add a **VBoxContainer** as root node. And add script below to this VBoxContainer node.

NOTE : **Lineedit** stretches because of **VBoxContainer**, not because of its own size value in this scene. Output of last two lines show this situation.

```
extends VBoxContainer

func _ready():
    var text = 'long text to test get_combined_minimum_size() function'

    # Add a label and resize to show all content
    var label = Label.new()
    label.set_text(text)
    label.set_name('Label')
    label.set('custom_colors/font_color', Color(0,0,0,1))
    print('label size : ' + str(label.get_size()))
    print('label combined_minimum_size : ' + str(label.get_combined_minimum_size()))
    label.set_size(label.get_combined_minimum_size())
    self.add_child(label)

    # Add a lineedit and resize to show all content
    var lineedit = LineEdit.new()
    lineedit.set_text(text)
    lineedit.set_name('Lineedit')
    print('lineedit size : ' + str(lineedit.get_size()))
    print('lineedit combined_minimum_size : ' + str(lineedit.get_combined_minimum_size()))
    lineedit.set_size(lineedit.get_combined_minimum_size())
    self.add_child(lineedit)

    print('label size after add_child : ' + str(label.get_size()))
    print('lineedit size after add_child : ' + str(lineedit.get_size()))
```

Console Output:

```
** Debug Process Started **
label size : 0,0
label combined_minimum_size : 324,13
lineedit size : 0,0
lineedit combined_minimum_size : 46,23
label size after add_child : 324,13
lineedit size after add_child : 46,23
```

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Android one-click deploy should ignore "Signed" export setting
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10, Godot nightly build (but applies to 2.0.3 and earlier)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It's possible to attempt a one-click deploy of an unsigned APK. This doesn't ever make sense. I'd expect the "Package/Signed" option to be ignore for one-click deployment. Not a HUGE issue but consider my use case where I need to export a release unsigned APK and so I have to check/uncheck this option when going between 1-click and export.
(edit: it's true I can 're-sign' an already signed APK and I will probably take advantage of that, but I think it's still something to consider.)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Set up Godot for Android 1-click deployment
Verify that a one-click deploy with "Signed" turned ON works ok
Un-check the "Signed" setting
Perform an Android one-click deploy
Note the deploy fails (silently; the command window shows that the install failed due to no certificate):

```
Installing into device (please wait..): Google Nexus 7
running cmdline: "H:/Android/sdk/platform-tools/adb.exe" "-s" "00ea7f8d" "install" "-r" "C:\Users\med\AppData\Roaming/Godot/tmp/tmpexport.apk"
3338 KB/s (7730287 bytes in 2.261s)
        pkg: /data/local/tmp/tmpexport.apk
Failure [INSTALL_PARSE_FAILED_NO_CERTIFICATES]

```

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
Any project that can deploy to Android.
